[Music]
Van started tracking the white van.
[Music]
All right, hello AI tinkerers, and welcome to One-Shot.
This is our global stage where we bring people from the community and give them a chance to go a little deeper, look under the hood, see if we can learn something from their projects.
And today, I am super excited.
I'm thrilled to have you.
This is Maxwell Wang, a software engineer at SpaceX and the creator of Drone Dispatcher, which is a side project that's incredible.
It's an AI-powered drone voice control.
I saw it on Twitter, and then I ran into you at the hackathon, and I saw it right away.
I knew exactly who you were, and I was just... and then you were tracking me moments later on your laptop, so it was awesome.
Thanks, Maxwell.
Yeah, it was really nice to meet you at the hackathon.
I didn't think you would be there, but yeah, I was glad to bring it out and show it to some people, and the reception seemed to be pretty good.
It's a pretty amazing project.
There's a lot of components to it, and um, I'm just excited to like dig in.
So why don't we get to like your background all that later and just dive right in?
Sure.
You want me to play the video?
Yeah, yeah, let's do that.
Drone Dispatcher, ready.
Over.
Can you go check how busy the nearest Trader Joe's is and route to the nearest Trader Joe's?
Drone's going a little slow.
Can you increase it to 10 m/s?
Speed set to 10 m/s.
Continuing to Trader Joe's.
Drone has arrived at Trader Joe's.
Traffic looks moderate.
You actually overshot a little bit.
Can you back up 50 m and then take a look?
Back up 50 m.
Positioned correctly.
Checking the area now.
Trader Joe's parking lot is visible now.
The parking area shows light to moderate activity.
Start tracking the white van.
[Music]
Van started tracking the white van.
If the drone's power is below 70%, please send it home.
[Music]
Drone's battery below 70%.
Returning home.
Area appears clear and suitable for landing.
Proceed with the return to home function.
Now, awesome, awesome.
Thank you.
Okay, super cool.
Obviously, a lot going on there when you consider all the pieces and the telepan and everything else.
Yeah, but why don't you, just for the sake of like understanding all that's there, from the moment someone says something like "back up 50 m" or "increase speed," what are all the pieces that are touched along the way?
Yeah, so whenever I like to explain this to people, I break it down into three components, and that's basically the architecture of the system.

So because it's over and it's like a... it works over a lossy connection, you can specify quality of service to retry until it happens.
